CV

About Me

I obtained my bachelor's degree in Computer Engineering from Shiraz University in August 2019, followed by a master's degree in Computer Systems and Architecture from Shahid Beheshti University in November 2021. In August 2022, I joined the Chair of Compiler Construction as a PhD Student at TU Dresden. In my current work, I focus on high-level compiler frameworks like MLIR, with a particular emphasis on optimizing data and computation mapping for highly heterogeneous systems. This includes various technologies such as CPUs, GPUs, and emerging in-memory computing systems like UPMEM and Samsung's HBM-PIM.

Main Publications

Cinnamon

ASPLOS 2025

CINM (Cinnamon) provides a novel compilation infrastructure based on MLIR that optimizes offloading kernels on compute-in-memory (CIM) and compute-near-memory (CNM) architectures for improved performance and energy efficiency.
  • Generalizes over heterogeneous Compute-in and Compute-near memory systems for device-agnostic optimizations.
  • Efficiently maps high-level operations to multiple hardware targets, including UPMEM and memristor-based systems.
  • Demonstrates significant performance improvements over hand-optimized code across various benchmarks.

C4CAM

ASPLOS 2024

C4CAM offers an compiler framework for CAM-based in-memory accelerators.
  • Automates the translation of high-level TorchScript code to CAM architectures.
  • Supports a wide range of CAM technologies and optimizes for power, latency, and utilization.
  • Demonstrates comparable performance and energy efficiency results to hand-crafted designs and GPU implementations.

SHERLOCK

DAC 2024

SHERLOCK efficiently schedules bulk bitwise operations in non-volatile memory (NVM), optimizing performance, energy, and reliability.
  • Introduces a novel mapping and scheduling framework for bulk bitwise operations in NVM-based compute-in-memory (CIM) systems.
  • Achieves up to 10x performance and 4.6x energy improvement over state-of-the-art solutions while considering reliability in decision failure rates.
  • Demonstrates significant gains across various applications, including databases, image processing, and encryption, using ReRAM and STT-MRAM technologies.
